body.div:
Annemarie Clarac-Schwarzenbach:
Letter from the Belgian Congo [ev. geplant als englischsprachige Veröffentlichung durch EM]
Lisala, July 17th, 1941
Dearest Erika, – we have to-morrow an airplane stopping
here on its way from Stanleyville down the river to the capital,
– and the very prospect to be able to mail a letter to you, which
eventually should arrive in the U.S., is a relief. It means, one is
still in contact with another life than the slow, heavy breath of
the jungle, and makes the pulse go a little faster.
Besides of myself, the shopkeepers among the fourty white of this
post are busy, too, to get some mail ready, – the others dont care
anymore. It seems The main event in the "brousse" – (which means
'jungle', and a lot more) is obviously the arrival of the riverboats
carrying fresh food, such as butter, meat, fruit, and vegetables,
mostly from the Cape. Since the stocks of French wine and Scotch
whisky are emptied, Colonial might even get used to drink
South African liquor. But they are conservative people, and at
present, nothing is left than some Congo beer. A few nights ago, I
have sorrowly finished with some friends from Luxembourg a last
bottler of Alsacian "Framboise", the combination with a dinner of
antilope roast was somehow old.
Yet, if you have just arrived from Europe, as I have seen it some
two months ago, you find no reasons to complain about war condi-
tions in the Congo. And it makes you feel alright to be in a
country which actually is at war.
Its contribution, I understand, is important.
It is normally important, first, to proove, that a European country
invaded and occupied by the Germans, is not in fact defeated.
Antwerp used to be the port for the Congo. Belgian industrial and
commercial companies in the Congo did all their business
through their main offices in the motherland.
Now the Germans control Antwerp and Bruxelles, yet they dont get
one grain of Congo coffee, not one once of gold, no copper, no tin,
no palm oil, no arachide, no copal,no cotton, tobacco or rice out
of this trimendously rich colony, – which is eighty times the size
of Belgium itself.
Yet, business in the Congo has not suffered. The output of copper,
tin and gold is even increaseing. Under the new trade agreement
with Great Britain, England buys almost the entire output of the
copper from the Katanga, of palme oil, and diamonds. The 500 000
onces of Congo fine gold a year is added to Britain's reserve.
The timber is sold to the South African Union. A good deal of
ores from the Congo are shipped to the U.S. for refining. The rest
remaining of the 1940 coffee crop is also sold on the New York
market.
As to the imports, there was of course a shortage right after the
invasion of Belgium. All European sources were suddenly closed, and
stocks in the country got exhausted. But the orientation towards
the South African Union, England, the U.S. and Canada began at once,
shipping from the Cape to the Congo port of Matadi is steadily
intreased, and the arrival of goods is by now fairly regular.
At the same time, agericultural production and local industries are
developping rapidly. In the Katanga, farmers now produce milk, butter
eggs, fruit, and vegetables, in the Kivu mountain regions they plant
tobacco and even tea, – indead, this country should be rich enough
to make its 30 000 White live on its own ressources [Kommentar zur kolonialen Logik dieses Satzes, da der großteil der eigentlichen Arbeit/Produktion durch die indigene Bevölkerung geschieht].
But there should be more roads, railroads, and airlines. While I was
in Leopoldville, I naturally could'nt realize that enormous parts of
the Congo are still untouched wilderness [damit meint AS: von Weissen nicht 'kultivierter' Regenwald, der jedoch Lebensgrundlage für die indigene Bevölkerung ist]. In order to reach Lisala,
some 800 miles up the river from Leo, I had to travel 7 days on a
riverboat, – and you saw day and night nothing than the trimendous
green walls of the jungle, – native villages beeing just tiny cleared
spots with dozen primitive huts and some wood biled up on the bank.
At night, we used to stop a few hours in order to load wood for our
engines, than we would carry on in the dim moonlight, winding through
thousands of islands covered with thick green.
From Leopoldville to Lisala, there is no road, only the river. And if
you look at the “brousse”, which is just like an ocean extending to
all sides and closing the horizon, you come to believe that you will
never find your way into an open space again. It is rather frightening.
Now, I am in this spot at the river since ten days, waiting for some
means of transportation to reach a plantation, some 200 miles inland.
If I am lucky, a lorry is going into that direction, some day. Mean¬
while I get to understand what people call here "to live en brousse".
Among the fourty white, there are some shopkeepers and agents,
selling goods to the black, and buying their product, mainly palm fruit
for their companies. They get percentages from what they sell, and if
they work hard, they can make some money. But in this climate – we are
in the Equator region – it takes a lot of energy to work.
The rest of the lot are government functionaries.
They work less. But at the end of a three years' term, functionnaries,
planters and sale agents are equally exhausted, and they need their
leave of six months badly.
As they cannot return to Europe, they now are sent to the Cape, or
into the Kivu mountains. But the change of climate in the Kivu is
not sufficiant.
As many young Belgians are mobilized in the Congo, there is a shor¬
tage of white labour in all branches. And you cant replace them, as
Belgians in the motherland are not allowed to leave,
nor can of course Dutch or French etc.
Most of the Colonials have relatives in Belgium, – especially
children, as they used to send them to school there. And most
of them get no news at all since the invasion.
Old colonials remember the last war. They know what a German
occupation means. You would think, that people in the colony
must be very war-conscious. But they also are tired of the war.
You cant plame them for it, – especially not in remote jungle
places where they spend years in a hard, dreary life fighting
against sickness, termites, and the incredible fatigue of the
heavy and solemn jungle. They say, that in the brousse even wild
animals get silent.
Still, there are two radios in Lisala, runned of course by batteries.
You always find somebody who is still interested enough to
listen in. You hear Brazzaville, Ankara, London, Moscouw, and very
often New York. It is almost a miracle. But than, many are not
capable anymore of a conscious effort,
they lack the imagination to realize that the human voices
speaking in the night belong to human beeings, alive, right now,
and at work in some building in far away cities, – and that the
trimendous events they are talking about, are going on, right
now, shaking the entire world, and that every bit of effort is
entering the same large stream towards victory.
But there are people enough, in the Congo, who do know. When I
had a chance, a few weeks ago, to talk to the Governor General,
Mister Ryckmans, I saw that the course of this country at the
side of Great Britain will be ready and the energy and courage
of its effort unbroken. Dont forget, also, that the government of
the Belgian Congo is in London ...
few While we were travelling up the river, we met in a small
post a young Belgian officer who was asking us the latest news
from Syria and North Africa. He was at this post since ten months,
training black soldiers. My comrades, two Free French officers,
on their way to Cairo, talked about the Syrian armistice, and that
General De Gaulle would now soon be [added to the left side: able] free to drive into Marocco.
The young Belgian looked at us with a grim expression of pain.
"Dont go to fast", he said, – "dont finish the job before I have
got a chance to fight on your side!" –
The two French officers should by now be in the Sudan. You can
reach Cairo from here in three or four weeks, and there are
airplanes, too. I hope to be on my way soon ...
But please, if you can, send me some news before that, to Leopold¬
ville, —
with all my love –
your
Annemarie
